metadata.title: Designing electron transporting layer for efficient perovskite solar cell by deliberating over nano-electrical conductivity

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Solar Energy Materials and Solar Cells
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/solmat
Designing electron transporting layer for efficient perovskite solar cell by deliberating over nano-electrical conductivity Sayantan Mazumdara,b, Bukui Dua, Chun Huanga,b, Peng Lina,∗∗, Jinlai Zhaoa, Xierong Zenga,b, Shanming Kea,c,∗ a Shenzhen Key Laboratory of Special Functional Materials & Shenzhen Engineering Laboratory for Advance Technology of Ceramics, College of Materials Science and Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, 518060, PR China b Key Laboratory of Optoelectronic Devices and Systems of Ministry of Education and Guangdong Province, College of Optoelectronic Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, 518060, PR China c School of Materials Science and Engineering, Nanchang University, Nanchang, 330031, Jiangxi, PR China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: nano-electrical conductivity Planar perovskite solar cell Electron transporting layer Conducting atomic force microscopy Pulsed laser deposition Thin film technology for photovoltaics
A B S T R A C T
Properties of the electron transporting layer (ETL) has paramount importance in determining the photovoltaic performance of perovskite solar cells (PSCs). Pulsed Laser Deposition (PLD) is proven to be a trustworthy process to deposit highly pure device-grade inorganic films on substrates, particularly that of metal oxides. In this study, TiO2 films are deposited on FTO substrates by PLD under various conditions and they are utilized as the ETL of PSCs. Remarkable change in photovoltaic performance is observed due to variation in deposition conditions of the TiO2 films. The best performing one is deposited at room temperature and yields in a PSC with 17% efficiency, hence, demonstrating that the PLD grown TiO2 films can achieve satisfactory performance in PSCs. Conducting-AFM characterization unveils that the nano-electrical properties differs phenomenally due to the deposition conditions which eventually determines the PV performances. Interesting nano-electrical features are observed in the pulsed laser deposited films and correlating the two-dimensional as well as the three-dimensional current maps with the PV performances, a pioneering approach of designing charge transport layer is proposed based on sole consideration of the nano-electrical properties.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Organo-metal halide light harvester based perovskite solar cells (PSC) have attracted tremendous interest in the field of solar energy conversion as its efficiency has increased faster than any other of its other contemporaries [1–4]. Large absorption coefficients, high charge carrier mobilities, long range exciton diffusion lengths of organo-lead halide perovskites enable PSCs to achieve outstanding light-to-electricity conversion efficiencies [5,6]. As efficiencies of PSC are drawing close to Si-based devices and also the stabilities are improving, it has attracted the industries owing to its low-cost and simpler preparation procedures. Meanwhile, prominent efforts have been put up in academia to not only increase the efficiency but also to study different properties of perovskites and other components and to develop novel materials, nanostructures and designs [7,8]. Though PSCs were initiated as sensitized solar cells where light harvesting perovskites are
utilized to sensitize thick mesoporous TiO2 layers, it has been realized soon that compact TiO2 layer would also be equally efficient as the electron transporting layer (ETL) or electron selective layer because the photogenarated excitons are primarily produced and transported in perovskite layer itself [1,3,9]. The organo-lead halide perovskite has outstandingly long charge-carrier diffusion length [5,10].
Though metal oxides like SnO2, ZnO, WOx, ZrO2, Nb2O5 and organic compounds [7,11–13] are reported as ETLs in planar PSCs, TiO2 prevails in most of the highly efficient planar or mesoporous PSCs [13–16]. As electron selective layers, ETLs also function as the hole blocking layer (HBL) which prevent the hole from reaching the optically transparent electrode (OTE). Therefore, the energy levels of a suitable ETL should align with that of the perovskite in such a way so that the electron injection and hole blocking can be facilitated simultaneously. In addition to the band alignment, the electron mobility of the ETL should be high and the ETL film should be enough porous to favor the

infiltration of the light harvester perovskite. Besides, the HBL should ideally be thin and dense to achieve good open circuit voltage and fill factor [14,17]. Taking into accounts the above requirement, wide band gap (3.2 eV for anatase) and suitable conduction band minimum of 4.1 eV makes TiO2 a suitable candidate for ETL. The conduction band minimum of TiO2 is marginally lower than that of CH3NH2PbI3 which facilitates photogenarated electron injection from perovskite to the ETL while its adequately low valence band maximum results in efficient blocking of hole [14]. Moreover, TiO2 enjoys the ease and flexibility of synthesis. It can be synthesized or can directly be deposited on a suitable substrate by many methods of solution-processing and physical deposition. Excellent control over morphology, nanostructures, doping, functionality, porosity, energy levels, electron mobility can be achieved by tuning the synthesis/deposition parameters [14,15,18,19].
Pulsed laser deposition (PLD) is one of the most advanced physical method to deposit high quality and reproducible films on a wide range of substrates. As it is a high vacuum process (< 1×10−4 Pa in our case), high purity films can be achieved, suitable for efficient devices [20–22]. A wide range of parameters associated with the PLD process like the fluence of the laser, repetition rate of the laser, lens type, background gas, target to substrate (T-S) distance, substrate type (absorption depth), temperature, deposition time can be tuned to achieve desirable films. Moreover, the architecture of the films can be engineered even at nanoscale by controlling the kinetic energy of the ablated species [23]. Pulsed laser deposited thin films have found a wide range of practical application in highly efficient devices. In realm of photovoltaics, PLD films are highly successful in second generation thin film based devices [24]. But, only sporadic literature can be found on application in sensitized solar cells or PSCs. On the other hand, PLD is proven to be a highly successful method in deposition of all major metal oxides including complex species. A great scope to study the effect of PLD grown film as ETL of PSCs is available. High purity, satisfactorily conducting and transparent TiO2 films can be obtained by PLD, suitable for energy devices [25]. Excellent control over TiO2 nanostructures also can be achieved by tuning the PLD parameters [19,26]. Though some reports on PLD deposited TiO2 films as ETL are available but, no detailed studies on the effect of various PLD parameters on the TiO2 films and subsequently on the photovoltaic (PV) efficiency of the PSC utilizing the TiO2 films are observed [19,26].
Herein, a wide range of TiO2 films are deposited on an OTE by PLD under varied conditions. Planar PSCs are fabricated utilizing those as the ETL. Significant change in PV performance is observed in different TiO2 films. An efficiency of 17% is achieved for the optimized TiO2 thin films as ETL, which is highest among the PLD deposited TiO2 film ETLs. To further elucidate the role of the properties of the TiO2 films in determining the PV performance of the devices, the nano-electrical conducting properties of some selected TiO2 films were studied by conducting-atomic force microscopy (c-AFM). c-AFM is proposed as an effective method to observe the conductivity of films at nanoscale and the current maps or the conductivity at nanoscale can be corresponded with device performances [11,27,28]. The nano-electrical conductivity maps in two dimension and three dimension are obtained and analyzed in details. Correlating the nano-electrical properties of the TiO2 film ETLs with the device performance, a novel approach of designing ETLs by solely considering and engineering the nano-electrical attributes is proposed.

sections.heading: 2.1. Pulsed laser deposition of TiO2 layer
sections.text:
A Fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) coated glass is used as the substrate for PLD deposition. The FTO substrate is cleaned by detergent solution (Micro-90, 2% in DI water), acetone, ethanol and DI water subsequently for 30min each. The substrate is attached with the PLD substrate stage and is placed inside the PLD chamber (Shenyang
Kecheng Technology Equipment Co., Ltd) for deposition. An excimer laser with 248 nm wavelength is subjected to a pure TiO2 target (polycrystalline, 99.99% pure, Hefei Kejing Materials Technology Co., Ltd). The fluence is adjusted to 42 mJ/pulse on the target with a 10 Hz repetition rate. The chamber is evacuated to< 1×10−4 Pa. Then the spinning target is subjected to the laser pulse under various O2 pressure. The number of pulses is varied so the deposition time. The temperature of the substrate that is the FTO coated glass, is varied from room temperature (RT) to 700 °C for different samples. The target to substrate distances are either 80mm or 50mm. After deposition, the heated substrates are cooled to room temperature under the same O2 pressure. All the substrates are annealed in air at 400 °C for 2 h in a muffle furnace. The annealed substrates are used for all the experiments and characterizations mentioned here. The PV results for not-annealed substrates are mentioned separately.

sections.heading: 2.2. Sample identification
sections.text: The following identification key is used in this paper to identify the samples fabricated under different PLD conditions, number of laser pulses (denoted by A, B, C)_ chamber O2 pressure (Pascal) _ substrate temperature. For number of pulses, A= 4500, B=9000, C=18000. The target to substrate distance is 80mm if it is not mentioned, otherwise it is mentioned as _50mm. So, C_RT_4Pa indicates a sample deposited at room temperature, under 4 Pa O2 pressure and 18000 laser pulses, target to substrate distance is 80mm. A_700_10−2Pa_50mm indicates a sample deposited at 700 °C substrate temperature under 10−2 Pa O2 pressure inside the PLD chamber and for 4500 laser pulses, target to substrate distance is 50mm.

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of planar perovskite solar cells
sections.text: The perovskite layer is deposited on the FTO substrates with TiO2 layer by an anti-solvent process. First, perovskite precursor solution with stoichiometric composition of FA0.75MA0.25PbI2.5Br0.5 is prepared by mixing FAI, MAI, PbI2 and PbBr2 in DMF and DMSO solution (1.25M with respect to Pb, DMF: DMSO=4:1). The precursor was then filtered with 0.22 μm PTFE syringe filter before spin coating. The TiO2 coated FTO substrates are subjected to ozone plasma for 10min before deposition of the perovskite layer. The perovskite layer deposition is carried out inside an Argon filled glove box. The perovskite precursor solution is spin-coated on the TiO2 coated FTO substrates. During the spin coating process, the spin rate is 1000 rpm for 10 s at the first step, and is then accelerated to 3000 rpm. After spin coating of 15s at 3000 rpm, Chlorobenzene (CB) is dropped onto the substrate quickly while spinning and the spin coating is carried out for another 15s continuously. After the completion of the spin coating process, the substrates are kept on hot plate at 100 °C for an hour. It facilitates the perovskite crystal growth and also the removal of the solvent. A spiroOMeTAD (80mg/mL in CB) solution with LTFSI (9.1 μg/mL) and 4-TBP (28.5 μL/mL) was then deposited onto the perovskite layer at 4000 rpm for 30 s which acts as the hole transport layer. Finally, 100 nm-thick gold electrode is deposited on it by a thermal evaporator at a rate of 0.1 nm/s. The active area of the device is 0.09 cm2 as determined by the mask covering the substrate during deposition of gold.

sections.heading: 2.4. Characterization
sections.text:
XRD of the films are carried out by a Bruker D8 Advance (Cu Kα1, λ=1.54Å) XRD system. Raman spectra of the samples are collected using a RENIDHAW invia Raman Microscope. XPS of the films are characterized by Microlab 350 system. The morphologies and the film thickness are observed using a Hitachi S4800 scanning electron microscope. The thickness of the films are further studied by an optical profilometer. The absorbance spectra of the films on the substrates are studied by a PerkinElmer Lambda 950 UV-VIS-NIR system. The
conductivity of the films are studied by a conductive atomic force microscope (c-AFM, Bruker Dimension Icon) in TUNA mode. The surface morphologies are also studied by the same instrument. An Ir–Pt tip with 25 nm radius coating a triangular silicon nitride cantilever is used. The tip and cantilever specifications are mentioned in the supporting information. The J-V measurements are carried out in ambient conditions with a Kiethly-2400 sourcemeter under simulated AM 1.5 G illumination (100 mW/cm2, Oriel Sol1A Class ABB solar simulator). The light intensity is calibrated with a Si-reference cell (NREL) attached with a power meter. The devices are characterized in a reverse voltage scan (negative to positive voltage).

sections.heading: 3.1. Pulsed laser deposition of TiO2 films and characterization
sections.text:
A highly pure TiO2 target is ablated by a Kr-excimer laser of 248 nm wavelength to deposit TiO2 on cleaned FTO substrates. Different conditions related to the PLD deposition are applied to achieve optimized films for PSCs. Samples are deposited at ambient temperature, 500 °C and 700 °C. After achieving high vacuum (< 10−4 Pa) inside the deposition chamber, high purity O2 gas is introduced slowly and laser ablation of the target is started only after reaching the desired O2 pressure. Different O2 pressures like 10−3 Pa, 10−2 Pa, 10−1 Pa, 4 Pa and 10 Pa are used. So, the samples are deposited under very low O2 pressures, few order of magnitude lower than the ambient conditions (105 Pa). All the samples are further annealed at 400 °C in air to ensure the formation of TiO2 and achieve good crystallinity. Effect of annealing of the TiO2 layers is also discussed in this paper in succeeding sections. The films are characterized by various methods to ensure the formation of TiO2 as well as the crystallinity. Peaks of anatase TiO2 are observed in the XRD patterns (Fig. S1) for all the samples, though the XRD peaks for FTO are more salient due to the high crystallinity and thickness of the commercial FTO films. Also, most of the anatase and FTO XRD peaks are overlapping. The short deposition time (minimum 4500 pulses) and long target to substrate distance (8 cm) result in a thin film. These lead to non-prominent X-ray diffractograms for TiO2. No significant peaks are observed in not-annealed samples deposited at room
temperature, which indicates the necessity of annealing to enhance TiO2 crystalinity. At least 300 °C substrate temperature is required for deposition of anatase TiO2 by PLD method while many reports suggested that post-deposition annealing at 500 °C is required to achieve mesoporous crystalline TiO2 films [15,29].
The formation of TiO2 films and the presence of anatase phase can be further confirmed by Raman spectroscopy and XPS studies of the as prepared films (Fig. 1). Fig. 1 (a) depicts the XPS spectra for the Ti 2p and O 1s of different samples and confirm the formation of TiO2. The O 1s XPS spectrum for bare FTO glass is markedly different from the O 1s XPS spectra of the TiO2 films. Only differences of few eVs of binding energies are observed between the peaks for different TiO2 samples which indicates similar bonding characteristics in different samples. Besides, anatase phase is evidenced in all the samples by the characteristic Raman peaks at 144, 399, 639 cm−1 (Fig. 1 (b)) [30].
The surface morphologies are observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (Fig. S2). No significant difference in nano-/microstructures is observed in TiO2 films deposited at different conditions. One significant feature of the as synthesized TiO2 films is, they are highly homogeneous but enough porous to facilitate ample diffusion of the perovskite precursor into the electron transporting TiO2. Physical deposition methods like PLD have this advantage of achieving highly homogeneous films over wet-chemical processes [19,24,31]. Optimized PLD conditions ensures satisfactory crystallinity of the epitaxial film which can improve photogenarated charge transport while maintaining sufficient porosity [19,23,31]. The fluence of the incident laser pulse on the target and the repetition rate of the laser pulse plays a key role in the formation of films. High energy pulses (100mJ compared to 42mJ used in this study) and lower repetition rate (5 Hz compared to 10 Hz in this study) results in a highly compact film [23,26]. Highly compact electron transporting layer may impede the diffusion of perovskite layer in the electron selective TiO2 film which can results in unsatisfactory photovoltaic performance of devices due to poor contact between the solar photon conversion layer and the electron transporting layer [26,31]. Hence, a mesoporous ETL must be introduced upon the compact layer in order to achieve a working device [26,32]. But, presence of two ETLs may cause increment of series resistance in the device and detrimental for PV performances. Similar microstructures and
morphological homogeneity of films have been found in simulated images as observed by AFM, which is described in succeeding sections. The thickness of the TiO2 films has increased with increasing deposition time. TheA_ RT_10−2Pa sample (4500 pulses) has a thickness of ∼37 nm while the C_RT_10−2Pa (18000 pulses) sample has a film thickness of ∼98 nm as observed in the cross-sectional SEM (Fig. S2). The films are found to be unstable under an electron beam. So, the cross-sectional SEM for other samples or more cross-sectional micrographs of the mentioned samples cannot be obtained. The thickness of the films are also measured by an optical profilometer. It is found that the thickness of the film deposited at ambient temperature, 10−2 Pa O2 pressure and 4500 laser pulses on the target is 42 nm. The film thickness increased to 72 nm for 9000 pulses and reaches to ∼100 nm for 18000 pulses. At higher O2 pressure of 4 Pa, the film thickness is 28 nm for 4500 pulses at ambient substrate temperature while the film thickness is ∼45 nm for the A_ 700_10−2Pa sample. The film thickness is not significantly increased at higher deposition temperature due to long T-S distance but O2 pressure affects the film thickness. As shown in the absorbance spectra of the films are presented in Fig. S3, all the films are transparent in visible range TiO2 has absorbance peak at UV region at ∼310 nm wavelength with a characteristic smaller peak at around 400 nm. The absorbance increases significantly with increasing deposition time i.e. more laser pulses. Higher O2 pressure leads to lesser absorbance and smaller T-S distance and that results in higher absorbance of the TiO2 films. The TiO2 film deposited at 700 °C markedly has a higher absorbance at ∼400 nm wavelength owing to higher crystallinity.

sections.heading: 3.2. Photovoltaic characterization
sections.text:
Planar perovskite solar cells are fabricated utilizing the pulsed laser deposited, epitaxially grown and annealed TiO2 films on FTO substrates. All the parameters namely the photo-harvesting perovskite
layer, the hole transporting layer, the hole collecting electrode are same for all the devices, only the ETL is varied. Hence, any variation in PV performance of the devices are induced by the ETLs. PV performances are evaluated by the J-V curve obtained under 100mW/cm2 of 1.5 G AM illumination. PV performance curves for all the samples are depicted in Fig. 2 and Fig. S4 and the values of PV performance parameters are scripted in Table 1. In Fig. 2, the effect of different PLD parameters are plotted in different graphs. In Fig. S4, all are plotted together for ease of comparison.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Effect of O2 pressure
sections.text:
PLD grown TiO2 films employed here as ETLs, are deposited under low pressures (10−1 Pa,10−2 Pa, 10−3 Pa, when the turbo-molecular pump is switched on to control the O2 pressure inside the deposition chamber) and relatively higher pressures (4 Pa, 10 Pa, the O2 pressure inside the deposition chamber is only controlled by the mechanical pump, turbo-molecular pump is switched off). The devices comprised of TiO2 films deposited at lower pressures evidently outperform those deposited at higher pressure (Fig. 2a).
For deposition at ambient temperature and 4500 pulses, the PV efficiency for the sample deposited at 10−2 Pa O2 pressure is 17%, seven times higher than that of the TiO2 film deposited at 4 Pa O2 pressure, 2.4%. All the PV parameters Jsc, Voc and fill factor are higher in the 10−2 Pa sample, particularly the short circuit current is three times higher (21.8mA/cm2 to 7.2 mA/cm2). When the O2 pressure is further increased to 10 Pa, the PV efficiency further decreases.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Effect of substrate temperature and deposition time
sections.text:
The effect of substrate temperature and deposition time i.e. number of incident laser pulses on the target, are depicted in Fig. 2b and (c) respectively. At ambient temperature deposition, when the number of laser pulses doubled to 9000, the Voc increases marginally, probably owes to the improved coverage of the optically transparent electrode
but, the Jsc and fill factor decreases which leads to the marginal decrement of the PV efficiency of the sample deposited for 9000 pulses to 15.7% compared to 17% efficiency of the sample deposited for 4500 pulses. When the deposition further increased to 18000 pulses i.e. for 30min, values of all the PV parameters decrease, especially the Jsc which decreases to 14mA/cm2 from 21.8mA/cm2 of the 4500 pulses sample. Hence, the PV efficiency decreases to 7.8%. Deposition is done at higher temperature of the substrate. PV efficiencies are 12.9% and 13.6% respectively for the A_500_10−2Pa and A_700_10−2Pa devices. Voc increases to 1.12 V at 700 °C compared to 1.08 V at room temperature deposited sample possibly due to enhanced coverage of the substrate and improved crystallinity. But, the decreased values of Jsc and fill factor leads to lower efficiency than that of the sample deposited at room temperature. TiO2 films are deposited for 9000 and 18000 pulses at 700 °C substrate temperature. The PV efficiency decreases marginally to 11.7% in case of B_700_10−2Pa device from 13.6% efficiency of A_700_10−2Pa device but significantly decreases to 3.2% for 30min deposition in the C_ 700_10−2Pa device. So, the effect of number of laser pulses or the deposition time is found to be similar in case of ambient temperature and high temperature deposition. Marginal decrement of PV efficiencies for 9000 pulses and significant decrement for 18000 pulses compared to 4500 pulses sample are observed in both ambient and high temperatures. Sample deposited for less than 4500 pulses results in lesser PV efficiencies and the results are not consistent and not reproducible, hence those are not reported here. Any intermediate temperature deposition does not result in higher PV efficiency and insignificant.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Effect of target to substrate distance
sections.text:
T-S distance can have a significant effect on pulsed laser deposited films. Depositions are carried out also at 5 cm T-S distance in contrary to 8 cm distances applied in all samples mentioned until here. The PV efficiency is decreased to 11.6% from 17% in 50mm sample compared to the 80mm sample when deposited at room temperature, 10−2 Pa O2 pressure and 4500 pulses (Fig. 2d). Both the Jsc and Voc decreases in 50mm T-S distance. In case of the 700 °C substrate temperature, the Voc decreases to 0.95 V for 50mm T-S distance compared to 1.12 V for
80mm T-S distance. In room temperature sample, the Jsc decreases minimally and the fill factor remains almost same. Overall, the PV efficiency is 10.8% in case of 50mm deposition compared to 13.6% in 80 cm deposition. So, it can be concluded that TiO2 film deposited at 80 cm T-S distance, which is the highest T-S distance possible inside the PLD chamber is resulting in best PV performances. It is also observed that the effect of T-S distance is more significant at ambient temperature deposition compared to higher temperature deposition.

sections.heading: 3.2.4. Effect of annealing
sections.text:
The effect of annealing of the pulsed laser deposited TiO2 films on the PV performance is also examined. Devices are fabricated utilizing the as deposited TiO2 films without annealing. The PV performances are furnished in Fig. S5 and Table S2. It is observed that the values of the PV parameters and the efficiencies are improved upon annealing. For example, in case of theA_ RT_10−2Pa sample the efficiency improves to 17% from 12.1% upon annealing at 400 °C in air while the efficiency increased to 13.6% from 10.1% upon annealing in A_700_10−2Pa sample. The effect of annealing is less prominent in PLD compared to wet-chemical methods because very important step of removal of organics is carried out by annealing in solution processed fabrication of metal oxides while in case of PLD, annealing can improve crystallinity as well as can assist in achieving stoichiometric compound [15].
So, it is observed that the optimized TiO2 film can be achieved at ambient substrate temperature, 10−2 Pa O2 pressure inside PLD chamber, 80mm target to substrate distance and deposition for 4500 laser pulses on target with 10 Hz repetition rate, 42mJ/pulse laser fluence. High temperature deposition cannot improve the efficiency. Though, post-deposition annealing is an important step here to achieve high performance devices. But, it must be considered that post-deposition annealing (400 °C for 2 h) is a simple process which is carried out in a muffle furnace in air. No special conditions are needed other than moderately high temperature of 400 °C. On the other hand, carrying out PLD in higher temperature such as 700 °C is a much complex process due to the need of highly controlled environment. It involves more energy input and time. Higher PV efficiency can be achieved by PLD deposition at room temperature than that of higher temperature
which is an advantage of our method.

sections.heading: 3.3. Nano-electrical characterization of PLD grown TiO2 films
sections.text:
In the PV characterization of the planar perovskite solar cells utilizing the PLD grown TiO2 films at different conditions as ETL, it is observed that the PV performances alter phenomenally with the deposition conditions of the TiO2 films. As no significant differences in morphologies at micro-/nano-scale or in other properties are noticed in different TiO2 films, it is rational to consider the conductive properties of the TiO2 films as a possible factor in determining the PV performances [11,27,33]. Nano-electrical characterization are carried out by means of conducting-atomic force microscopy (c-AFM) on selected TiO2 films including the best performing one. Four samples are chosen namely, A_RT_10−2Pa, A_700_10−2Pa, C_RT_10−2Pa, A_RT_4Pa to examine the effect of substrate temperature, deposition time and O2 pressure. Current mapping is done in TUNA mode on 2 μm×2 μm areas of all the samples and representative micrographs are furnished in Fig. 3. The same micrographs are again presented in Fig. S6, side by side with the corresponding height profiles of the same areas for ease of comparison.
As four samples with varied conductive regions are studied, the VIBGYOR scale is chosen to present the currents where violet indicates highest currents → red indicates lowest currents. This color Scheme adoption felicitates the detection of even delicate variation in conductivity and the difference in conductivity between samples are prominent. Conductivity of nanosized regions are clearly visible and differentiable with each other. The three dimensional projections of the same micrographs are presented in Fig. 4 which are useful in observing the in-depth conductivity scenarios of the TiO2 films.
The A_RT_10−2Pa sample consists of highly conducting nanosized zones as marked by violet color, surrounded by less conducting regions identifiable by green to red colorization. The current map imitates highly conducting regions like islands in sea of insulating or less-conductive regions. The highly conducting violet colored regions visible on surface continue vertically towards the substrate as visible from the 3D current map. These imitate nanorod like one dimensional highly conducting regimes vertical to the OTE. The A_700_10−2Pa sample has almost continuous highly conducting regions marked by violet with few marginally less conducting regions in indigo. The same conductivity scenario continues vertically towards the OTE. The current map of the C_RT_10−2Pa sample predominantly contains green-yellow regions
with rare blue areas and with many broad low conducting red areas. The less conducting regions identifiable by red coloration on current maps are more clearly visible in the 3D projection and those are elongated to the OTE. Comparing the 3D height profile (Fig. S7) with the 3D current map, it is found that the less-conducting regions are not formed because of absence of TiO2, TiO2 is homogeneously present but forms insulating or less-conducting regions, in that case.
The A_RT_4Pa sample is almost homogeneously blue-green with few nanometer sized violet conducting regions which found out to be narrow conducting satellites from the 3D current maps. The same scenarios have been observed when the current map is collected at 5 μm×5 μm areas of the samples, following the homogeneity of the PLD grown films (Fig. S8).
The 3D current maps (height profiles and current maps in Fig. S9) at broader areas depict the same scenario found at while scanning a smaller area. The 3D current maps of three samples are furnished in Fig. S10, supporting the findings of Fig. 4 in larger area. The 3D current map of C_RT_10−2Pa are presented in another suitable angle in Fig. S10 (c2) where the less conducting regions elongated up to the OTE from the surface are clearly visible.

sections.heading: 3.4. Consideration of nano-electrical conductivity in ETL design
sections.text:
In the nano-electrical characterization of the PLD grown TiO2 films by means of c-AFM, it is observed that the A_RT_10−2Pa sample contains nanorod like charge conduction regions vertically aligned to the electrode, surrounded by insulating regions. It can facilitate unidirectional photocurrent conduction from the light harvester perovskite to the current collecting FTO electrode [34–37]. The A_700_10−2Pa sample contains continuous high conducting regions compared to the island-like (but homogeneous over large area) high conducting regions of A_RT_10−2Pa. But, it may cause scattered or non-unidirectional photocurrent flow. It completely supports the PV performance result where the A_RT_10−2Pa device exhibits greater Jsc and fill factor than that of the A_700_10−2Pa device. The high temperature deposition may lead to improved coverage of the electrode, results in higher Voc and continuous high conductive regions but, the isolated, one-dimensional, high conductive structure of A_RT_10−2Pa can facilitate superior photocurrent conduction to the OTE and results in a high efficiency planar perovskite solar cell. Longer deposition time increases the thickness of the film but the conductivity reduces significantly with notable
Scheme. Proposed ETL design. TiO2 film deposited at room temperature contains vertically aligned 1D conducting channels which facilitates unidirectional charge transfer to electrode. High temperature deposited sample has continuous conducting regions which may lead to multi-directional flow of photogenarated charge which causes loss of charges. Longer deposition time leads to less-conducting film. This 1D conducting channels proposes a new designing strategy for ETL or any charge transporting layers in energy devices.
presence of insulating regions, which indicates nano-electrical inhomogeneity for longer deposition or thicker films, as observed in the C_RT_10−2Pa sample. Homogeneous less-conducting film is deposited at higher O2 pressure of 4 Pa as found in A_RT_4Pa sample. Though few narrow conducting satellites are present, they are not sufficient to increase the photocurrent transportation significantly. These make the PV performances of C_RT_10−2Pa and A_RT_4Pa devices inferior than A_RT_10−2Pa and A_700_10−2Pa devices.
The effect of nano-electrical properties of the TiO2 films further reflected in impedance spectroscopy of the devices. Impedance spectroscopy is an effective tool to elucidate ac-conducting properties in devices [23,38]. The ac-impedance spectra are recorded for all the four devices under 1 sun illumination and the Nyquist plots are furnished in Fig. S11. Though the data cannot be fit to get exact resistance values, it is clearly visible from the diameter of the semi-circles that the resistance of the A_RT_10−2Pa and A_700_10−2Pa devices are approximately 100Ω and 200Ω respectively.
The impedance of C_RT_10−2Pa and A_RT_4Pa devices are much higher than the other two and of few thousands ohm. The TiO2 films are also subjected to Hall measurements and the values of the parameters are furnished in Table S3. A_RT_10−2Pa and A_700_10−2Pa has lower resistivity and higher mobility than other two samples. C_RT_10−2Pa sample has compatible electron mobility but higher resistivity and the 4 Pa deposited sample has lower mobility and higher resistivity.
Morphologically one dimensional structures of wide band gap oxide materials such as nanorods, vertically aligned on electrodes are proposed as efficient ETL not only for perovskite solar cells, also for Quantum dot solar cells and other solar energy conversion devices [34,38,39]. Morphologically one dimensional structures contains a risk of touching the hole transport layer, infiltrating the solar photon harvesting material [19,26,35,40]. It has detrimental effect on PV performances. Herein, the A_RT_10−2Pa film imitate vertically aligned one dimensional structure only in the nano-electrical regime and results in a highly efficient planar perovskite solar cell with a power conversion efficiency of 17%, which is highest among the PLD grown TiO2 films.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: Herein, it is demonstrated that homogeneous and state of the art TiO2 films can be synthesized by PLD method and can be tuned by various PLD parameters to achieve an effective film for highly efficient planar perovskite solar cells. The nano-electrical conductivity scenarios of the PLD grown films are investigated by c-AFM and correlation between nano-electrical conductivity of the films and the performance of planar perovskite solar cells fabricated using them as ETL has been established. This work proposes an unprecedented designing strategy of the ETL, reckoning on the nano-electrical properties or nano-current mapping. Following this study, novel ETL can be engineered to fabricate films with one-dimensional conducting channels to achieve efficient PSCs or other devices. The same design can be employed on other ETL materials or hole transporting materials for inverse planar devices. This can trigger manifold of deposition/synthesis strategies to achieve efficient ETLs following the design to achieve efficient devices not only for perovskite solar cells but for any metal oxide based devices.

metadata.abstractText: Properties of the electron transporting layer (ETL) has paramount importance in determining the photovoltaic performance of perovskite solar cells (PSCs). Pulsed Laser Deposition (PLD) is proven to be a trustworthy process to deposit highly pure device-grade inorganic films on substrates, particularly that of metal oxides. In this study, TiO2 films are deposited on FTO substrates by PLD under various conditions and they are utilized as the ETL of PSCs. Remarkable change in photovoltaic performance is observed due to variation in deposition conditions of the TiO2 films. The best performing one is deposited at room temperature and yields in a PSC with 17% efficiency, hence, demonstrating that the PLD grown TiO2 films can achieve satisfactory performance in PSCs. Conducting-AFM characterization unveils that the nano-electrical properties differs phenomenally due to the deposition conditions which eventually determines the PV performances. Interesting nano-electrical features are observed in the pulsed laser deposited films and correlating the two-dimensional as well as the three-dimensional current maps with the PV performances, a pioneering approach of designing charge transport layer is proposed based on sole consideration of the nano-electrical properties.
